pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 193, 304, 209]]<|/det|>
# FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 216, 156, 231]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 193, 907, 250]]<|/det|>
9231/13 May/June 2013 3 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 259, 467, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF10)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 322, 390, 339]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 351, 828, 366]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 367, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 384, 327, 399]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 400, 497, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 416, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 447, 285, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 462, 907, 493]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 494, 504, 509]]<|/det|>
The use of a calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 509, 907, 540]]<|/det|>
Results obtained solely from a graphic calculator, without supporting working or reasoning, will not receive credit.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 540, 606, 556]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 570, 606, 585]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 586, 757, 602]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 97, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 75, 715, 109]]<|/det|>
Let \(\operatorname {f}(r) = r! (r - 1)\). Simplify \(\operatorname {f}(r + 1) - \operatorname {f}(r)\) and hence find \(\sum_{r = n + 1}^{2n} r! (r^2 + 1)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[887, 81, 917, 101]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 141, 97, 160]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 139, 920, 193]]<|/det|>
The roots of the equation \(x^{4} - 4x^{2} + 3x - 2 = 0\) are \(\alpha , \beta , \gamma\) and \(\delta\); the sum \(\alpha^{n} + \beta^{n} + \gamma^{n} + \delta^{n}\) is denoted by \(S_{n}\). By using the relation \(y = x^{2}\), or otherwise, show that \(\alpha^{2}\), \(\beta^{2}\), \(\gamma^{2}\) and \(\delta^{2}\) are the roots of the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[381, 192, 615, 214]]<|/det|>
\[y^{4} - 8y^{3} + 12y^{2} + 7y + 4 = 0.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[887, 195, 920, 214]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 230, 450, 250]]<|/det|>
State the value of \(S_{2}\) and hence show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[410, 255, 588, 276]]<|/det|>
\[S_{8} = 8S_{6} - 12S_{4} - 72.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[887, 255, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 310, 96, 329]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 308, 648, 329]]<|/det|>
Prove by mathematical induction that, for every positive integer \(n\),

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[353, 336, 645, 365]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\mathrm{d}^{n}}{\mathrm{d}x^{n}} (\mathrm{e}^{x} \sin x) = (\sqrt{2})^{n} \mathrm{e}^{x} \sin (x + \frac{1}{4} n \pi).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[887, 343, 920, 362]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 408, 96, 427]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 403, 665, 435]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}} = - \frac{4}{3}\) at the point \(A\) (1, \(-2\)) on the curve with equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 441, 571, 462]]<|/det|>
\[y^{3} - 3x^{2}y + 2 = 0,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 470, 364, 507]]<|/det|>
and find the value of \(\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}y}{\mathrm{dx}^{2}}\) at \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 478, 920, 497]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 540, 96, 560]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 532, 378, 570]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\int_{0}^{1}x\mathrm{e}^{-x^{2}}\mathrm{d}x = \frac{1}{2} - \frac{1}{2\mathrm{e}}.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 540, 920, 560]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 579, 616, 621]]<|/det|>
Let \(I_{n} = \int_{0}^{1}x^{n}\mathrm{e}^{-x^{2}}\mathrm{d}x\). Show that \(I_{2n + 1} = nI_{2n - 1} - \frac{1}{2\mathrm{e}}\) for \(n \geqslant 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 590, 920, 609]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 628, 329, 647]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of \(I_{7}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 628, 920, 647]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 676, 96, 695]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 673, 732, 696]]<|/det|>
The linear transformation \(\mathrm{T}: \mathbb{R}^{4} \to \mathbb{R}^{4}\) is represented by the matrix \(\mathbf{M}\), where

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[366, 700, 635, 772]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{M} = \left( \begin{array}{cccc} -2 & 5 & 3 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & -4 & -2 \\ 6 & -14 & -13 & 1 \\ \alpha & \alpha & -2\alpha & -11\alpha \end{array} \right)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 777, 920, 813]]<|/det|>
and \(\alpha\) is a constant. The null space of T is denoted by \(K_{1}\) when \(\alpha \neq 0\), and by \(K_{2}\) when \(\alpha = 0\). Find a basis for \(K_{1}\) and a basis for \(K_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 794, 920, 813]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 892, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the value of the constant \(\lambda\) such that \(\lambda x\mathrm{e}^{- x}\) is a particular integral of the differential equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[403, 100, 920, 133]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}y}{\mathrm{dx}^{2}} +5\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}} +4y = 6\mathrm{e}^{-x}. \quad [4]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 154, 796, 183]]<|/det|>
Find the solution of the differential equation for which \(y = 2\) and \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}} = 3\) when \(x = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 163, 920, 181]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 214, 96, 234]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 214, 855, 234]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has parametric equations \(x = \frac{3}{2} t^2, y = t^3\), for \(0 \leqslant t \leqslant 2\). Find the arc length of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 216, 920, 235]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 246, 920, 265]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of the centroid of the region enclosed by \(C\), the \(x\)-axis and the line \(x = 6\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 247, 920, 265]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 293, 96, 311]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 293, 920, 344]]<|/det|>
The square matrix \(\mathbf{A}\) has an eigenvalue \(\lambda\) with corresponding eigenvector \(\mathbf{e}\). The non-singular matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) is of the same order as \(\mathbf{A}\). Show that \(\mathbf{M}\mathbf{e}\) is an eigenvector of the matrix \(\mathbf{B}\), where \(\mathbf{B} = \mathbf{M}\mathbf{A}\mathbf{M}^{-1}\), and that \(\lambda\) is the corresponding eigenvalue.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 327, 920, 345]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 356, 151, 374]]<|/det|>
<label>Let</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 371, 583, 425]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{A} = \left( \begin{array}{ccc} - 1 & 2 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 4 \\ 0 & 0 & 2 \end{array} \right).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 428, 700, 446]]<|/det|>
Write down the eigenvalues of \(\mathbf{A}\) and obtain corresponding eigenvectors.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 428, 920, 447]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 459, 207, 477]]<|/det|>
Given that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 476, 578, 529]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{M} = \left( \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right),\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 532, 581, 551]]<|/det|>
find the eigenvalues and corresponding eigenvectors of \(\mathbf{B}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 532, 920, 551]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 578, 104, 597]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 578, 668, 597]]<|/det|>
Use the identity \(2 \sin P \cos Q \equiv \sin (P + Q) + \sin (P - Q)\) to show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 604, 663, 636]]<|/det|>
\[2\sin \theta \cos (\theta - \frac{1}{4}\pi)\equiv \cos (2\theta -\frac{3}{4}\pi) + \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 656, 920, 691]]<|/det|>
A curve has polar equation \(r = 2 \sin \theta \cos (\theta - \frac{1}{4}\pi)\), for \(0 \leqslant \theta \leqslant \frac{3}{4}\pi\). Sketch the curve and state the polar equation of its line of symmetry, justifying your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 675, 920, 694]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 704, 645, 723]]<|/det|>
Show that the area of the region enclosed by the curve is \(\frac{3}{8} (\pi + 1)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 705, 920, 723]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[322, 816, 677, 834]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Question 11 is printed on the next page.]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 102, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 527, 92]]<|/det|>
Answer only **one** of the following two alternatives.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 114, 201, 129]]<|/det|>
# EITHER

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 144, 920, 210]]<|/det|>
The line \(l_{1}\) passes through the point \(A\) whose position vector is \(4\mathbf{i} + 7\mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k}\) and is parallel to the vector \(3\mathbf{i} + 2\mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k}\). The line \(l_{2}\) passes through the point \(B\) whose position vector is \(\mathbf{i} + 7\mathbf{j} + 11\mathbf{k}\) and is parallel to the vector \(\mathbf{i} - 6\mathbf{j} - 2\mathbf{k}\). The points \(P\) on \(l_{1}\) and \(Q\) on \(l_{2}\) are such that \(PQ\) is perpendicular to both \(l_{1}\) and \(l_{2}\). Find the position vectors of \(P\) and \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 193, 920, 210]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 222, 920, 255]]<|/det|>
Find the shortest distance between the line through \(A\) and \(B\) and the line through \(P\) and \(Q\), giving your answer correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 240, 920, 257]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 285, 153, 301]]<|/det|>
<label>OR</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 316, 507, 333]]<|/det|>
Show the cube roots of 1 on an Argand diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 316, 920, 333]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 346, 920, 380]]<|/det|>
Show that the two non-real cube roots can be expressed in the form \(\omega\) and \(\omega^2\), and find these cube roots in exact cartesian form \(x + \mathrm{i}y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 364, 920, 381]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 394, 322, 410]]<|/det|>
Evaluate the determinant

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[421, 410, 583, 465]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 3\omega & 2\omega^2 \\ 3\omega^2 & 2 & \omega \\ 2\omega & \omega^2 & 3 \end{vmatrix} .\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 431, 920, 448]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 483, 920, 517]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(z = (4\sqrt{3})(\cos \frac{4}{3}\pi + \mathrm{i}\sin \frac{4}{3}\pi) - 4(\cos \frac{11}{6}\pi + \mathrm{i}\sin \frac{11}{6}\pi)\). Express \(z\) in the form \(r(\cos \theta + \mathrm{i}\sin \theta)\), giving exact values for \(r\) and \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 504, 920, 521]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 532, 591, 549]]<|/det|>
Hence find the cube roots of \(z\) in the form \(r(\cos \theta + \mathrm{i}\sin \theta)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 532, 920, 549]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]
